content.sentence:
What does an electrical technician do?

An electrical technician installs and maintains wiring systems in buildings.

What does an electrical technician do?

He tests circuits and repairs damaged cables during maintenance work.

What does an electrical technician do?

He uses tools such as pliers, multimeters, and screwdrivers every day.

What does an electrical technician do?

He doesn’t switch off the main power before connecting new wires.

What does an electrical technician do?

He reads circuit diagrams and follows electrical blueprints carefully.

What does an electrical technician do?

He does not ignore safety rules when working with live wires.

What does an electrical technician do?

He checks voltage levels and replaces blown fuses when needed.

What does an electrical technician do?

He connects lighting fixtures, switches, and sockets correctly.

What does an electrical technician do?

He does not wear insulated gloves or safety boots while repairing circuits.

What does an electrical technician do?

He records all test results and reports faults to the supervisor.

content.intro: The ElectroTest 250 Digital Multimeter is a versatile device used to measure electrical quantities such as voltage, current, and resistance in electrical systems.

subsections.subtitle: Main Components
items: LCD Display – shows the measurement readings clearly.
Function Selector Dial – used to choose the type of measurement (V, A, Ω, continuity, etc.).
Input Terminals (COM, VΩmA, 10A) – connection points for test leads.
Test Leads (Red & Black) – connect the multimeter to the circuit or component under test.
Power Button – turns the device on or off.
Hold Button – freezes the reading on the screen.
Battery Compartment – located at the back of the unit.
Protective Rubber Casing – shields the meter from damage in workshop environments.

steps: Insert a fresh 9V battery into the compartment before use.
Connect the black lead to the COM terminal and the red lead to the correct terminal for your measurement.
Turn the selector dial to the desired function (e.g., DC voltage).
Place the leads across the component or circuit to take a reading.
Observe the measurement on the LCD display.
Press the Hold button if you want to freeze the value.
When finished, turn off the multimeter and disconnect the leads.
notes: Warning: Always start with the highest range and move down gradually to avoid damaging the unit.

subsections.subtitle: Common Issues and Solutions
items: No Display: Check or replace the battery.
Fluctuating Readings: Ensure leads are properly connected; avoid contact with wet surfaces.
No Continuity Beep: Replace the internal fuse if necessary.
Overload Symbol Appears: Measurement range is too low — increase it using the selector dial.

subsections.subtitle: Maintenance Tips
items: Keep the test leads clean and untangled.
Store the multimeter in its protective case.
Avoid measuring live circuits above the maximum rated voltage.
Calibrate annually for professional accuracy.
Never use a damaged test lead or probe.
Do not measure current in household mains without proper training.
Always disconnect power before testing resistance.
Avoid exposure to moisture and direct sunlight.
Turn off the unit after each use to extend battery life.
